definitions: small round cake made from flour, butter, and milk, often containing fruit
examples: She served warm scones with clotted cream for afternoon tea
The bakery sells fresh blueberry scones every morning

definitions: deep spoon-like tool for serving ice cream or other foods
important news story obtained exclusively by one journalist or organization
rounded mass of something served with a scoop utensil
examples: She used an ice cream scoop to serve perfect portions
The metal scoop helps measure coffee grounds precisely
The reporter got a major scoop about the political scandal
Their newspaper published the scoop before any competitors
He ordered two scoops of vanilla ice cream with chocolate sauce
Add one scoop of protein powder to your smoothie

definitions: child's toy vehicle with handlebars, deck, and two wheels
small lightweight motorcycle with a step-through frame and platform
examples: The child rode her pink scooter around the playground
He performed tricks on his stunt scooter at the skate park
She commutes to work on an electric scooter every day
The Vespa scooter became an icon of Italian design

definitions: extent of the area or subject matter that something deals with
telescope or other optical instrument for viewing distant objects
examples: The scope of the project expanded beyond our initial expectations
This issue falls outside the scope of our investigation
The sniper adjusted the scope on his rifle carefully
They observed the stars through a powerful telescope scope

definitions: mark or discoloration caused by burning or excessive heat
examples: The iron left a scorch on her favorite silk blouse
There were scorch marks on the kitchen counter from hot pans

definitions: number of points achieved in a game or test
written or printed form of a musical composition showing all parts
group or set of twenty items historically used in counting
examples: The final score was three to two in overtime
She received a perfect score on her mathematics exam
The conductor studied the orchestral score before the performance
He bought the piano score of his favorite Broadway musical
Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth
They ordered three score eggs from the farm

definitions: large board displaying the score and other information at a sports venue
examples: The scoreboard showed two minutes left in the fourth quarter
Fans cheered as their team's name climbed the scoreboard

definitions: card for recording scores during a game or evaluating performance metrics
examples: He marked his golf scorecard after each hole carefully
The company uses a balanced scorecard to track business performance

definitions: player who scores points or goals in a game or competition
examples: She was the team's leading scorer with thirty goals this season
The tournament's top scorer received a golden boot trophy

definitions: act of gaining points or goals in a game or competition
process of making cuts or marks on a surface for a purpose
examples: The team's scoring improved dramatically in the second half
His scoring average ranks among the best in league history
Scoring the dough helps the bread expand while baking
The craftsman began scoring the glass before breaking it

definitions: feeling or expression of contempt or disdain for someone or something
examples: She looked at him with scorn after hearing his excuse
His suggestion was met with scorn from the committee members

definitions: predatory arachnid with eight legs and a venomous stinger at the end of its tail
examples: The desert scorpion glowed under ultraviolet light at night
She found a scorpion hiding under a rock in the garden

definitions: whisky distilled in Scotland from malted barley and other grains
transparent adhesive tape used for joining or mending paper
examples: He ordered a single malt scotch on the rocks
The bar stocks several premium scotch whisky brands
She used scotch tape to wrap the birthday present
Can you pass me the scotch tape from the drawer?

definitions: person who behaves badly or dishonestly, especially someone who deceives or cheats others
examples: That scoundrel cheated dozens of elderly people out of their savings
The novel's villain was a charming scoundrel with no morals

definitions: thorough and energetic search of an area or resource for something
examples: Police conducted a scour of the neighborhood for the suspect
The treasure hunters began their scour of the ancient ruins

definitions: person or thing that causes great trouble, suffering, or destruction
whip used as an instrument of punishment, especially historically
examples: Poverty remains a scourge in many developing nations worldwide
The disease was a scourge that decimated entire populations
The medieval painting depicted monks using a scourge for penance
The prisoner faced punishment with the dreaded scourge

definitions: vigorous cleaning or scrubbing of something to remove dirt
act of searching thoroughly and carefully through an area
examples: The scouring of the pots took hours after the feast
Regular scouring keeps the bathtub free from soap scum
Their scouring of the archives revealed important historical documents
The detective's scouring of evidence led to new leads

definitions: person sent ahead to gather information about enemy positions or terrain
member of the Scout organization that teaches outdoor skills to youth
examples: The military scout reported enemy movements near the border
The talent scout discovered several future stars at the audition
My son became an Eagle Scout after years of dedication
The scout troop went camping in the mountains last weekend

definitions: act of exploring or searching an area to gather information
activities and programs of the Scout movement for youth development
examples: The team spent weeks scouting locations for the film
His scouting of new talent helped build a championship team
She learned valuable life skills through years of scouting
Scouting teaches children outdoor survival and leadership skills

definitions: adult leader in charge of a Scout troop who guides and trains young scouts
examples: The scoutmaster taught the boys how to tie various knots
Our scoutmaster organized monthly camping trips for the troop

definitions: large flat-bottomed boat with square ends used for transporting freight
examples: The scow carried construction materials across the harbor
Workers loaded sand and gravel onto the industrial scow

definitions: board game where players form words from individual lettered tiles
frantic scratching or scrambling movement with hands or paws
examples: We play Scrabble every Sunday evening with the family
She scored fifty points with one word in Scrabble
The dog's scrabble at the door meant he wanted outside
There was a desperate scrabble for the last tickets

definitions: quick and awkward movement or climb using hands and feet
dish of eggs stirred and cooked quickly while mixing
encoding of a broadcast signal to prevent unauthorized reception
examples: There was a mad scramble for seats when doors opened
The hikers had to scramble over loose rocks
He made a quick scramble with cheese for breakfast
The restaurant serves the best veggie scramble in town
The cable company uses signal scramble to protect premium channels
Military communications employ sophisticated scramble technology

definitions: electronic device that encodes signals to prevent unauthorized interception
motorcycle designed for both on-road and off-road riding
examples: The military uses a voice scrambler for secure communications
They installed a scrambler on the telephone line
He bought a vintage scrambler motorcycle for weekend adventures
The scrambler handled both city streets and dirt trails well

definitions: small piece or fragment of something, especially paper or fabric
waste material that can be reused or recycled, especially metal
informal fight or quarrel between people
examples: She wrote the phone number on a scrap of paper
There wasn't a scrap of evidence to support his claim
The junkyard buys scrap metal by the pound
They collected scrap iron for the war effort
The boys got into a scrap over who won the game
There was a minor scrap between rival fans after the match

definitions: book with blank pages for sticking photographs, newspaper cuttings, and other memorabilia
examples: She created a scrapbook of her daughter's first year
His baseball scrapbook contained tickets and programs from every game

definitions: mark or wound caused by scraping against a rough surface
difficult or embarrassing situation that someone gets into
harsh grating sound produced by dragging something across a surface
examples: The child had a scrape on her knee from falling
There were several scrapes on the car's bumper
He got into a scrape with the law over unpaid fines
She helped him out of a financial scrape
The scrape of chalk on the blackboard made everyone cringe
We heard the scrape of chairs being moved upstairs

definitions: tool with a flat blade used for scraping surfaces clean or smooth
examples: He used an ice scraper to clear the windshield
The paint scraper removed old layers from the wooden door

definitions: act of removing something from a surface by dragging a tool across it
small amount of something obtained by scraping
examples: The scraping of old paint took all afternoon
We could hear the scraping of metal against concrete
She collected scrapings from the bowl to test
DNA scrapings were taken from under the victim's fingernails

definitions: mark or wound made by scratching or scraping a surface
starting point or baseline with no advantage or handicap
examples: The cat left a deep scratch on the leather sofa
She covered the scratch on her phone screen with tape
They built the business from scratch with no investors
He learned to cook from scratch using basic ingredients

definitions: act of rubbing or scraping with fingernails or claws
DJ technique of moving a vinyl record back and forth on a turntable
examples: The dog's constant scratching indicated a flea problem
The scratching at the door grew more insistent
His scratching skills made him a popular club DJ
The DJ's scratching added rhythm to the hip-hop track

definitions: loud, high-pitched cry expressing fear, pain, or excitement
person or thing that is remarkably funny or outrageous
examples: Her scream alerted neighbors to the break-in
The roller coaster riders let out screams of excitement
That comedian is an absolute scream at parties
The movie was a scream from start to finish

definitions: person who screams frequently or makes very loud sounds
newspaper headline in very large print designed to grab attention
examples: The lead singer was known as a screamer in the metal band
The baby was a real screamer during the night
The tabloid ran a screamer about the celebrity scandal
The newspaper's screamer announced the election results

definitions: act of making loud, high-pitched cries or sounds
examples: The screaming from the haunted house attraction could be heard outside
There was constant screaming during the horror movie

definitions: mass of small loose stones that form on a mountain slope
examples: The climbers carefully navigated the unstable scree slope
Scree covered the base of the cliff after the rockfall

definitions: loud, harsh, piercing cry or sound
examples: The owl's screech echoed through the forest at night
The car tires made a screech as the driver braked suddenly

definitions: act of making loud, harsh, high-pitched sounds
examples: The screeching of brakes warned pedestrians of danger
The screeching from the microphone feedback hurt everyone's ears

definitions: flat surface on which images or data are displayed electronically
fixed or movable upright partition used to divide a room or give shelter
mesh or perforated material used to filter or protect from insects
examples: She stared at her computer screen for hours while working
The movie looked amazing on the giant IMAX screen
They placed a decorative screen to separate the dining area
The nurse pulled the privacy screen around the hospital bed
The window screen kept mosquitoes out during summer nights
He cleaned debris from the pool filter screen

definitions: showing of a film or video to a selected audience
systematic testing or examination to detect a condition or assess suitability
process of passing material through a screen to separate particles
examples: The premiere screening attracted hundreds of film critics
They organized a private screening for industry professionals
The airport screening process detected prohibited items
All employees undergo background screening before hiring
The screening of sand removes larger stones and debris
Screening the topsoil produced fine planting material

definitions: written text of a film including dialogue, action descriptions, and scene directions
examples: She won an Oscar for best original screenplay
The screenplay adaptation stayed faithful to the novel

definitions: person who writes screenplays for films or television
examples: The screenwriter spent months perfecting the dialogue
Famous screenwriters often command high fees for their work

definitions: metal fastener with a helical thread that is driven into material by rotation
ship's or aircraft's propeller
examples: He tightened the screw to secure the shelf bracket
The furniture came with all necessary screws and bolts
The ship's screw churned the water as it departed
A twin-screw vessel has better maneuverability

definitions: person who behaves in a strange or eccentric way
baseball pitch that curves in the opposite direction from a curveball
examples: That screwball always has the wildest ideas at meetings
The movie featured a lovable screwball character
The pitcher's screwball confused even experienced batters
He threw a perfect screwball for the strikeout

definitions: tool with a shaped tip that fits into screw heads for turning them
cocktail made with vodka and orange juice
examples: Pass me the Phillips screwdriver to fix this cabinet
He kept a set of screwdrivers in his toolbox
She ordered a screwdriver at the Sunday brunch
The bartender made a perfect screwdriver with fresh orange juice

definitions: person who copied documents by hand before printing was invented
pointed tool for marking lines on material to be cut
examples: Medieval scribes preserved ancient texts in monasteries
The scribe carefully copied the illuminated manuscript
The carpenter used a scribe to mark the cutting line
A scribe helps ensure accurate woodworking measurements

definitions: practice game between members of the same team in sports
confused struggle or fight involving several people
examples: The coach scheduled a scrimmage before the season opener
Players improved their skills during the afternoon scrimmage
A scrimmage broke out between protesters and police
There was a brief scrimmage for the loose ball

definitions: certificate or receipt used as substitute for money
written authorization or certificate, especially for medicine
examples: The company paid workers in scrip redeemable at company stores
During the shortage, they issued scrip instead of cash
The doctor wrote a scrip for antibiotics
She took the scrip to the pharmacy immediately

definitions: written text of a play, film, or broadcast
particular style or system of writing
program or sequence of instructions for a computer
examples: The actors rehearsed their lines from the script
She submitted her script to several production companies
Children learn cursive script in elementary school
The ancient script was difficult to decipher
The programmer wrote a script to automate the backup process
This Python script processes data files automatically

definitions: sacred writings of a religion, especially the Bible in Christianity
examples: The minister read scripture during the Sunday service
Many find comfort and guidance in scripture

definitions: person who writes scripts for films, television, or radio
examples: The scriptwriter adapted the novel for television
Experienced scriptwriters understand pacing and dialogue
